name: OmniBus
description: OmniBus is next-to-last gen physics game about the most powerful bus in the universe that can’t stop or even slow down for reasons incomprehensible to the simple human mind.
minimum_requirements: 最低: OS: Windows Vista or Later プロセッサー: 2.4 GHz Intel Core 2 Duo or better メモリー: 2 GB RAM ストレージ: 200 MB 利用可能 追記事項: A government issued license to drive an out of control bus.

reviews.review_text: It's difficult, but not frustrating. The levels are challenging enough to make you want to beat them, without being unfair or seemingly impossible. Well worth the money, it's a lot of fun. Each level is entirely different from the rest, and gameplay never gets boring.

Omnibus is a good game, that would be better if with tighter mechanics. I get the joke of having wonky physics or a bus that easily flips over, but you're going to spend a lot of time in air not playing the game and landing upside down to start the level over from instant death. The joke wears thin quickly.  The joke of odd physics is way funnier when something looks initially real, or when something is going right like racing well in Burnout only to crash into a million pieces. The graphics here are Jaguar level and the bus is too unwieldy to feel like you're doing well.  Imagine if rather than being qwop/happy wheels inspired this game played with the tightness of controls Rocket League has. The levels could be scaled to be harder and you'd have a more fun game, one that was overall less frustrating.  Omnibus is still a good game though. It's really varied in terms of level type, and the final boss even has you use all the basic mechanics to beat the game (something that many modern games forget to do.) You can also skip any level which is nice if you get fed up. I beat the game at 5 hours skipping 2 levels.  I'd really like them to take another shot with this concept. Take the silliness out of the controls and put it into more of their inventive level ideas!
